elements.text:
!

I wrote an email a while ago to someone that had a similar question, hopefully it's useful:

It's a useful tool, and I use it a lot for one purpose: quickly understanding the related topics that top-ranking articles also reference. If I want to write a canonical article on a particular topic, it's a useful complement to the qualitative research I run.
With that said, I have some issues with the concept of the tool:

It can't differentiate between keywords that are repeatedly mentioned because they're integral to the topic, and those that are mentioned just because they're used as illustrative examples. If two articles use the same illustrative example - say "Apple" - Clearscope treats the use of the keyword "apple" as a ranking factor, even if the topic has no relevance to Apple. We regularly receive SEO briefs that are tantamount to plagiarism because they use Clearscope and don't make this distinction.

It encourages mindless "optimization" at the expense of good, well-structured writing. Trying to cram 15 keyword variants into an article gives me flashbacks to the bad old days of SEO, and it sends our writers a mixed signal - improving the Clearscope score usually degrades the quality of a piece.

Customers take the Clearscope score at face value and assume that anything less than A+ sucks - despite the fact that most currently top-ranking content doesn't get an A+. Instead of critically evaluating the quality of the writing, the angle we've taken, and so on, they latch onto the score because it's easily understood and communicated.

Ultimately, it creates copycat content. It's a tool for emulating existing search results, and encourages people to consolidate existing information instead of adding anything new to the topic. It's a good tool for writing "skyscraper content," but it's actively harmful for any other types of content.
tl;dr - useful if applied in the right way, with potential downsides for thoughtless useless

text: Awesome, thanks <@UJ3K7N8GJ>! That's how I felt about Frase as well--my team was way too caught up on the score it spit out. Wasn't sure if Clearscope had any other (worthwhile) features, so that's good to know. Great article, thanks for sharing!

text: I'm trying to figure out how to make a webhook list GDPR compliant. If you're using a Mailchimp sign up form, double optin is easy peasy. Our list is built from a Slack signup form so I'm not quite sure how to do this.
